sen.j: 源 融（みなもと・の・とおる、弘仁13年（822年） - 寛平7年8月25日 (旧暦)（895年9月21日））は、嵯峨天皇の12男。
sen.e: MINAMOTO no Toru (822 – 21 Sep 25, 895) was the 12th son of Emperor Saga.
MINAMOTO no Toru (822 – 21 Sep 25, 895) was the 12th son of Emperor Saga.
MINAMOTO no Toru (822 – September 25, 895) was the 12th son of Emperor Saga.
sen.cmt: 没年月日を修正しました。

sen.j: 侍従、右衛門督。
sen.e: Chamberlain, emonnokami (Captain of the Right Division of the Outer Palace Guards).
He was chamberlain and emonnokami (Captain of the Right Division of the Outer Palace Guards).
He was a jiju (chamberlain) and Uemon no kami (Captain of the Right Division of Outer Palace Guards).
sen.cmt: 日本名の役職（英語の補足）の表現にしました。

sen.j: 大納言などを歴任し、従一位左大臣にいたる。
sen.e: Successively held positions of Dainagon (Chief Councilor of State) and Juichii-sadaijin (Junior First Rank - Minister of the Left).
He held positions including Dainagon (Chief Councilor of State), reaching the position of Juichii-sadaijin (Junior First Rank - Minister of the Left).
He held positions including Dainagon (Chief Councilor of State), reaching the position of Juichii Sadaijin (Junior First Rank - Minister of the Left).
sen.cmt: Sadaijin と大文字にしました。

sen.j: 別名河原左大臣。
sen.e: He was also known as kawara-no-sadaijin (Minister of the Left for Kawara).
He was also known as kawara-no-sadaijin (Minister of the Left for Kawara).
He was also known as kawara-no-sadaijin (Minister of the Left for Kawara).

sen.j: 死後正一位を追贈された。
sen.e: After death he was posthumously conferred the court title of Shoichii (Senior First Rank).
He was posthumously awarded the title of Shoichii (Senior First Rank).
He was posthumously awarded the title of Shoichii (Senior First Rank).

tit.cmt: I have no idea why 肖像 has been used here, but judging by the information that follows, something like "Biography" should be OK, I think.

sen.j: 嵯峨源氏融流初代。
sen.e: Founder of the Toru branch of the house of Saga Genji.
He founded the Toru branch of the house of Saga Genji
He founded the Toru branch of Saga-Genji (Minamoto clan).
sen.cmt: 嵯峨源氏→Saga-Genji (Minamoto clan) としました。

sen.j: 紫式部『源氏物語』の主人公で美男子の光源氏の実在モデルとする説がある。
sen.e: There are stories that the handsome man named Hikaru Genji who is leading character in "Tale of Genji" by Shikibu MURASAKI was actually modeled on MINAMOTO no Toru.
There is a theory that the handsome Hikaru Genji, the leading character in "Tale of Genji" by Shikibu MURASAKI, was actually modeled on MINAMOTO no Toru.
There is a theory that the handsome Hikaru Genji, the leading character in "Tale of Genji" by Shikibu MURASAKI, was actually modeled on MINAMOTO no Toru.

sen.j: 陸奥国塩竈市の風景を模して作庭した河原院（現在の渉成園）を造営したといい、世阿弥作の能『融』の元となった。
sen.e: With Shiogama City in Mutsu Province as a backdrop, it is said he worked as a gardener during the building of Kawaranoin Temple (present day Shoseien gardens) and, was the inspiration for "Toru", a traditional Japanese Noh play written by Zeami.

It is said that he created a garden modeled on a view of Shiogama City in Mutsu Province during the building of Kawaranoin Temple (present-day Shoseien gardens) and, was the inspiration for "Toru", a traditional Japanese Noh play written by Zeami.
sen.cmt: I think "を模する" can be tranlsated as "modeled on".
sen.e: It is said that he created a garden modeled on a view of Shiogama City in Mutsu Province during the building of Kawaranoin Temple (present-day Shoseien gardens) and, was the inspiration for "Toru," a traditional Japanese Noh play written by Zeami.

sen.j: また、別邸の栖霞観の故地は今日の嵯峨釈迦堂清凉寺である。
sen.e: In what were then the surroundings of the "Seikakan"detached residence today can be found the Saga-shakado Seiryo-ji Temple.
In what were then the surroundings of the "Seikakan"detached residence today can be found the Saga-shakado Seiryo-ji Temple.
In what were then the surroundings of the "Seikakan" detached residence today can be found the Saga Shakado Seiryo-ji Temple.

sen.j: 六条河原院の塩釜を模すための塩は、難波の海（大阪湾）の北（現在の尼崎市）の汐を汲んで運ばれたと伝えられる。
sen.e: It has been said that to replenish the salt cellar at the Rokujo-Kawaranoin Estate, salt water was drawn and carted from north of what was then called the Sea of Namba (Osaka Bay) at present day Amagasaki City.
It has been said that to replenish the salt cellar at the Rokujo-Kawaranoin Estate, salt water was drawn and carted from north the Sea of Namba (Osaka Bay) at present day Amagasaki City.
It has been said that to replenish the salt cellar at the Rokujo-Kawaranoin Estate, salt water was drawn and carted from north the Sea of Namba (Osaka Bay) at present day Amagasaki City.

sen.j: そのため、源融が汐を汲んだ故地としての伝承がのこされており、尼崎の琴浦神社の祭神は源融である。
sen.e: The legend of the surrounding area where MINAMOTO no Toru drew salt water has been handed down and for that reason, the deity enshrined at Kotoura-jinja Shrine in Amagasaki is MINAMOTO no Toru.
The story about where MINAMOTO no Toru drew salt water has been handed down, and the deity enshrined at Kotoura-jinja Shrine in Amagasaki is MINAMOTO no Toru.
The story about where MINAMOTO no Toru drew salt water has been handed down, and the deity enshrined at Kotoura-jinja Shrine in Amagasaki is MINAMOTO no Toru.

sen.j: 後に左大臣に昇ったが、藤原基経が陽成天皇の摂政ついで太政大臣に任じられて政治の実権を握ったために、基経との政治的権限の衝突を恐れて貞観_(日本)18年（876年）頃より自宅に引籠もった（『三代実録』及び『中右記』）。
sen.e: Later on he was promoted to the position of Sadaijin (Minister of the Left) however, FUJIWARA no Mototsune was appointed Regent to Emperor Yozei and incidentally Daijodaijin (Grand minister of State) as a means to grasp political power. Due to concerns about conflicts in political authority with Mototsune, he shuttered himself at home from 876. ("Sandaijitsuroku" and "Chuyuki".

He was later promoted to the position of Sadaijin (Minister of the Left), but when FUJIWARA no Mototsune came to power as Regent to Emperor Yozei and subsequently Daijodaijin (Grand minister of State), there were concerns about conflicts in political authority with Mototsune, and he confined himself to his residences from 876. ('Sandaijitsuroku' and 'Chuyuki').
sen.cmt: I think the translator used "incidentally" where he/she meant "subsequently".
sen.e: He was later promoted to the position of Sadaijin (Minister of the Left), but when FUJIWARA no Mototsune came to power as Sessho (Regent) to Emperor Yozei and subsequently Dajo-daijin (Grand minister of State), there were concerns about conflicts in political authority with Mototsune, and he confined himself to his residences from 876 ("Sandai Jitsuroku" (sixth of the six classical Japanese history texts) and "Chuyuki" (Diary of a court official)).
sen.cmt: 文献名の補足を追加しました。

sen.j: 光孝天皇の即位後の元慶8年（884年）頃に基経と融の政治権限の分担が明確化されたために再び政務に参加するようになった。
sen.e: Circa 884 following the enthronement of Emperor Koko, in order to clarify the respective political authority of Mototsune and Toru, he again engaged in government business.
Circa 884, after the enthronement of Emperor Koko, division of political authority between Mototsune and Toru was clarified, and so Toru returned to the government.
Circa 884, after the enthronement of Emperor Koko, division of political authority between Mototsune and Toru was clarified, and so Toru returned to the government.

sen.j: なお、陽成天皇の譲位で皇位を巡る論争が起きた際、自分も皇胤の一人であると主張したが藤原基経に退けられたという。
sen.e: A dispute pertaining to the throne took place amongst the children of Emperor Yozei and, even though he emphasized he was one of the children, he was dismissed by FUJIWARA no Mototsune.
On the abdication of Emperor Yozei, there was a dispute about the succession, and although Toru put himself forward as a potential successor, he was pushed aside by FUJIWARA no Mototsune.
sen.cmt: The Japanese doesn't specify that it was the children who were disputing the succession.
sen.e: On the abdication of Emperor Yozei, there was a dispute about the succession, and although Toru insisted that he was one of the descendant of an Emperor, he was pushed aside by FUJIWARA no Mototsune.
sen.cmt: 「皇胤の一人である」というニュアンスを出すため、翻訳を一部変更しました。

sen.j: （『大鏡』） また融の死後河原院は息子の源昇が相続、さらに宇多天皇に献上されており、上皇の滞在中に融の亡霊が現れたという伝説が『今昔物語』『江談抄』等に見える。
sen.e: "Large Mirror"("Okagami"): Following the death of Toru, his son MINAMOTO no Noboru inherited the Kawaranoin Estate which was presented again to Emperor Uda and, there is a legend that an apparition of the departed Toru appeared during a visit by a retired Emperor which can be read about in the "Tale of Konjaku" and. "Godansho" etc.

"Large Mirror"("Okagami"): Following the death of Toru, the Kawaranoin Estate passed to his son MINAMOTO no Noboru and was then presented to Emperor Uda, and in "Tale of Konjaku" and. "Godansho" it is said that Toru's ghost appeared during visit by the retired Emperor.

("Large Mirror" (Okagami)); Following the death of Toru, the Kawaranoin Estate was passed to his son MINAMOTO no Noboru and was then presented to Emperor Uda, and in "Konjaku Monogatari" (The Tale of Times Now Past) and "Godansho" (the Oe Conversations, with anecdotes and gossip) it is said that Toru's ghost appeared during visit by the retired Emperor.
sen.cmt: 文献名の補足を追加しました。

sen.j: 現在の平等院の地は、源融が営んだ別荘だったもの。
sen.e: The grounds of present day Byodoin Temple are the site of the villa belonging to MINAMOTO no Toru.
The villa belonging to MINAMOTO no Toru was situated in what are now the grounds Byodoin Temple.
sen.cmt: More natural with "the villa" as the subject.
sen.e: The villa belonging to MINAMOTO no Toru was situated in what are now the grounds of Byodoin Temple.

Toru branch of the house of Saga Genji
MINAMOTO no Toru branch of Saga-Genji (Minamoto clan)
tit.cmt: 嵯峨源氏→Saga-Genji (Minamoto clan) としました。

sen.j: 嵯峨源氏において子孫を長く伝えたのは源融の流れを汲み、地方に下り武家となった融流嵯峨源氏である。
sen.e: Amongst all the offspring of the Saga Genji family, themes relating to MINAMOTO no Toru has been explored for eons and, the Toru branch of the family is a military family that relocated to the countryside.
Of the descendents of the Saga Genji family, the MINAMOTO no Toru branch, which relocated to the countryside and became military family, is the longest.
Of the descendents of the Saga-Genji (Minamoto clan), the MINAMOTO no Toru branch, which relocated to the countryside and became military family, is the longest.
sen.cmt: 嵯峨源氏→Saga-Genji (Minamoto clan) としました。

sen.j: その代表が摂津国(大阪)の渡辺氏であり、祖の渡辺綱（みなもと・の・つな）は源融の孫の源仕の孫に当たり、母方の摂津国渡辺津に住み、渡辺氏は大内守護（天皇警護）の滝口武者の一族に、また瀬戸内の水軍の棟梁氏族となる。
sen.e: Representing this is the Watanabe clan of Settsu Province (Osaka) whose ancestors include WATANABE no Tsuna who was grandchild of MINAMOTO no Tsukau who was in turn MINAMOTO no Toru's grandchild. On his maternal side, he lived with Watanabe-no-tsu in Settsu Province: the Watanabe Clan being a household of Takiguchi-no-musha who were Ouchishugo (emperor's bodyguards) and also, a leading clan in the Setouchi navy.
sen.cmt: Original text appears to be faulty 渡辺綱（みなもと・の・つな）
sen.e: One clan in the Toru branch was the Watanabe clan of Settsu Province (Osaka) who were descenced from WATANABE no Tsuna, the grandchild of MINAMOTO no Tsukau, who was the grandchild of Toru. WATANABE no Tsuna lived in Watanabe-no-tsu in Settsu Province, the territory of his mother's family, and the Watanabe Clan would provide Takiguchi-no-musha who were Ouchishugo (emperor's bodyguards), and a became a leading clan in the Setouchi navy.

One clan in the Toru branch was the Watanabe clan of Settsu Province (Osaka) who were descended from WATANABE no Tsuna, the grandchild of MINAMOTO no Tsukau, who was the grandchild of Toru; WATANABE (MINAMOTO) no Tsuna lived in Watanabe-no-tsu in Settsu Province, the territory of his mother's family, and the Watanabe clan became Takiguchi-no-musha who were Ouchi Shugo (safeguard of the Imperial Palace), and a became a leading clan in the Setouchi navy.
sen.cmt: 大内守護、棟梁氏族となった、という表現に変更しました。

sen.j: 渡辺綱の子あるいは孫の渡辺久は肥前国松浦郡の宇野御厨の荘官となり松浦久と名のり、松浦郡の地頭の松浦氏は、肥前国の水軍松浦党の棟梁氏族となる。
sen.e: WATANABE no Tsuna's grandchild (child of Hisashi WATANABE) took his name from UNO no Mikuriya who went by the name of Hisashi MATSUURA, and was a shokan (village elder) in Matsuura Country in Hizen Province. The Matsuura Clan were lords of Matsuura Country and a leading clan of the Matsuura naval faction in Hizen Province.

WATANABE no Tsuna's son (or grandson) took his name became shokan (administrator) of Matsuura Country in Hizen Province under UNO no Mikuriya, and took the name of Hisashi MATSUURA. The Matsuura Clan were lords of Matsuura Country and a leading clan of the Matsuura naval faction in Hizen Province.

WATANABE no Hisashi, who was a WATANABE no Tsuna's son (or grandson), became shokan (administrator) of Uno no mikuriya (a manor of Imperial family and powerful shrines) in Matsuura district in Hizen Province, and took the name of Hisashi MATSUURA; Matsuura clan, who was the jito (manager and lord of manor) in Matsuura district, became a leading clan of the Matsuura naval faction in Hizen Province.
sen.cmt: 御厨の補足を追加しました。地頭 を補足しました。

sen.j: 筑後国(福岡県柳川市)の蒲池氏も源融の子孫であり、源融の孫の源是茂（源仕の弟）の孫の源貞清の孫の源満末が肥前国神埼郡の鳥羽院領神埼庄の荘官として下り、次子（あるいは孫）の源久直が筑後国三潴郡の地頭として三潴郡蒲池に住み蒲池久直と名のる。
sen.e: The Kamachi clan of Chikugo Province (Yanagawa City, Fukuoka Prefecture) are also descendents of MINAMOTO no Toru. The grandson of MINAMOTO no Toru`s grandson MINAMOTO no Koreshige (MINAMOTO no Tsukau's younger brother) had a grandson named MINAMOTO no Sadakiyo who had a grandson named MINAMOTO no Mitsusue who was shokan (village elder) of Kanzaki manor which was the domain of the retired Emperor Toba. Also, the second child (and grandchild) MINAMOTO no Hisanao were lords of Mizuma County in Chikugo Province and as such lived at Kamachi in Chikugo Province so, took the name "Hisanao KAMACHI".

The Kamachi clan of Chikugo Province (Yanagawa City, Fukuoka Prefecture) are also descendents of MINAMOTO no Toru. The MINAMOTO no Toru's grandson, MINAMOTO no Koreshige (MINAMOTO no Tsukau's younger brother) had a grandson named MINAMOTO no Sadakiyo who had a grandson named MINAMOTO no Mitsusue who was shokan (administrator) of Kanzaki manor, the domain of the retired Emperor Toba. Also, the second child (or grandchild) MINAMOTO no Hisanao bcame lords of Mizuma County in Chikugo Province, living in Kamachi in Chikugo Province and taking the name "Hisanao KAMACHI".

The Kamachi clan of Chikugo Province (Yanagawa City, Fukuoka Prefecture) are also descendents of MINAMOTO no Toru; the MINAMOTO no Toru's grandson, MINAMOTO no Koreshige (MINAMOTO no Tsukau's younger brother) had a grandson named MINAMOTO no Sadakiyo who had a grandson named MINAMOTO no Mitsusue who was shokan (administrator) of Kanzaki manor, the domain of the retired Emperor Toba; also, the second child (or grandchild) MINAMOTO no Hisanao became a jito of Mizuma district in Chikugo Province, living in Kamachi in Chikugo Province and taking the name Hisanao KAMACHI.
sen.cmt: 翻訳を一部修正しました。セミコロンで文章を接続しました。

sen.j: 蒲池氏の末裔でもある西国郡代の窪田鎮勝（蒲池鎮克）の子で二千石の旗本の窪田鎮章が、幕将として幕末の鳥羽伏見の戦いで討ち死にした際、大坂の太融寺で葬儀が行われた。
sen.e: He was a distant relative of Shigeaki KUBOTA of the Kamachi Clan who received a 2,000 koku retainer directly from the shogun, and who was a child of the Saigoku (Western Province) bailiff named Shigekatsu KUBOTA (Shigekatsu KAMACHI). However, KUBOTA died in battle in the Toba Fushimi War during the closing days of the Tokugawa shogunate and a funeral service was conducted at Taiyu-ji Temple in Osaka.

Shigeaki KUBOTA, who was a child of the Saigoku (Western Province) bailiff and Kamachi clan-descendent Shigekatsu KUBOTA (Shigekatsu KAMACHI) and who received a 2,000 koku stipend directly from the shogun fought and died in battle in the Toba Fushimi War during the closing days of the Tokugawa shogunate and a funeral service was conducted at Taiyu-ji Temple in Osaka.

Shigeaki KUBOTA, who was a child of the Saigoku gundai (an intendant of Western Province) and Kamachi clan-descendent Shigekatsu KUBOTA (Shigekatsu KAMACHI) and who received a 2,000 koku stipend directly from the shogun, fought and died in battle in the Battle of Toba-Fushimi during the closing days of the Tokugawa shogunate and a funeral service was conducted at Taiyu-ji Temple in Osaka.
sen.cmt: 西国郡代の補足を追加しました。
